name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: Law and Order

transcript.content: Aristotle once observed, law is order and good law is good order. A seemingly simple concept, but the realities of making those good laws and enforcing them have troubled society since time immemorial. From community service to capital punishment, everyone has a view on how we protect the innocent and punish the guilty. Is one man's law another man's tyranny? Is justice available to all? Does prison work? Should we lock up law breakers and throw away the key? Or does that fail to address the root causes of crime? To discuss these questions and more, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington. Look at that fucking head.
Right.
So, Karl, law and order.
I'm not that interested in it to be honest.
What do you mean?
I've got no interest in law and order whatsoever. It's not part of my life. That's the problem. You keep picking topics that don't buzz me.
Of course they do.
They don't.
Well, let's talk about this. Let's talk about this.
You're a man quite obsessed with law and order.
Based on what?

Well, law and order is basically to protect the innocent, isn't it? I mean, when we think of law and order, we usually think of crime and punishment, but it's all about protect our person. We have the right to walk the streets without getting mugged when someone wrongs us. We want justice. It's fundamental. And you do. You were sitting in your old flat in London in front of me every day that you wanted to go downstairs and smack their heads in for being late and shouting around and being drunk, and you could hear it. You wanted some justice.
Yeah, but nothing would have happened if I called someone up and said, there's people doing noise pollution, even though there's a law for noise pollution now, it's not really taken seriously, is it?
But you are concerned with law and order.
No, but there's no point.
You wanted your rights. And you ended up moving. He's moved here now. He's moved to lovely sunny Hampstead, just down the road from us. So you're having a better life.
I shouldn't have to move because of some noisy people?
No, you shouldn't, but I'm saying you were stressed-
No one cares though.
-and you wanted justice, but you thought you couldn't get justice, so you moved away which is-
So I dealt with it in my way.
Yeah.
I hated them because they didn't care about anyone else.
Exactly.
The police wouldn't get involved. There's other people who live around there who had to put up with it. No one cared.
So what did it feel like every night when you were trying to watch telly and it's hot and you got the window open? All yeah.

You could just hear stuff it's that thing of you get a lot of tourists in London, so they talk. And it's not even as if you can listen into what they say and have a view on their opinion, because they're foreign.
Would that be entertaining for you.
Well, yeah, because if you can hear what people are saying. You're going "Oh yeah that's a good point"
"Switch the tele off" [laughing] that's a good point?
I don't want to hear anyone talking.

I'll tell you what, I really feel sorry for people with like, neighbours from hell because I'm not saying it's just fine, but I can see why people go mental with someone when they're bullied or constantly harassed and no one cares. And when you can't go to the police, you can't go to police and go "there's a bloke next door, he's got his tele on too loud. He's always pissed. He's shouting about. If you don't do something, I'm going to go around there and crack his head in. You'd be the one that...
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
"No"
Oh no. How embarrassing.
It was unbelievable
Being told off is the worst.

It's because there's people walking by and I'm being told off by a woman who is at least a foot and a half shorter than me, wearing a uniform, and it was so embarrassing. It was so cripplingly embarrassing.
Yeah

"Let me ask you again, have you got a ticket?" - "No, I haven't" - "So you lied" - "Yes, I did, yeah" - "Okay, were gonna have to take your details" But honestly, being told, and that's it, the shame. Maybe it's a good bit of upbringing, unlike Karl obviously, who's a man who's got no guilty conscience at all about the whole Mars Bar incident, but whereas you and I, Rick, were raised obviously by better parents, and we are - its been drummed into us.
How much was that train journey?
Ricky Laughs

You know we do feel that guilt and that's maybe one of the reasons why we don't transgress. This is an interesting - we talked earlier about the murder, thing. Of course, there's that sort of idea, which has often been used in films, in a godless universe, and if you do not feel guilt, what's to prevent you from committing murder? If you can get away with it. If you could commit to murder, let's say you wanted to, and you could get away with it, there is no one to judge you in a godless universe, and you can live with the guilt, what's to stop you doing it?

Well, I just like to say now, it is a godless universe, as an atheist, there is no God and I'm a good person, not because I want to get rewarded for it in heaven, because that's how I want to live my life, in a society that treats people like that. So a lot of the laws of the land, not just in England, in many countries, are from the Bible. I mean, that kicked it off. I mean, there was laws before, obviously, and there were different gods before this one, was invented, but let's have a look at the Ten Commandments.
Oh, yeah

I think that lays down most of the uh, a lot of them are good rules of thumb. We got to go along with them. They certainly didn't invent those, rules of thumb. I think that mankind were adhering to most of them before it - was handed down. So let's have a look at them. There's a website here, a Baptist Christian website forum. And this guy, maybe I shouldn't say his name, I mean, he's put it out there for public, but I don't want to embarrass him. He says, "Brethren and Sistren."

Ricky is reading from the Landover Baptist Church website [www.landoverbaptist.net/showthread.php?t=16785], a parody fundamentalist Baptist church he seemingly mistakes as legitimate. An example of "Poe's Law" - where without a clear indicator of the author's intent, any parodic or sarcastic expression of extreme views can be mistaken by some readers for a sincere expression of those views.
What? Never heard that before.
Yeah, I've learnt a word, brothers and sisters.
Could have said sisters.
Could have said people.
He could've said people, could've said folks.

"It has come to my attention that not only are many of our members unable to correctly recite all the Ten Commandments." It's probably a big problem. I don't know whether he goes around testing them, going, "Number Three? - Umm... - Get out! Go and learn it!", "but those who can remember, even a few, invariably get the sequence wrong"
Is that important?
Oh, well, it is. He says, "Let me set the record straight. The commandments do not come in a random sequence, with the exception of 7th commandment, an obvious anomaly."
Why?
Well, he reckons that thou shalt not commit adultery at number seven should really be 6th in terms of severity. Let me explain, "The commandments appear in order of severity"
Right

"The harsher the punishment, the closer to the top. I hope this handy color chart will make the intrinsic beauty of God's word more comprehensible to all." So this is it, he's laid it out. "Commandment Number One, Thou shalt have no other gods before me" Okay, "Alert level: Severe, Punishment: Genocide."
Whoa!

"Entire cities with men, women, children and animals must be killed", So that's a lovely, nice Christian view there. So if you worship another god before the right God, he doesn't name him by name, he just uses the term God.
Sure.
But there's only one, according to this.
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
Where is gold bullion kept?

I don't know. I suppose you go and get it from a, vault somewhere and take it away and take delivery of it. I don't know if it literally changes hands, or not. So what they need is obviously my passport. So they got the people. So it was going to go to court. I didn't have to go to court, but I had to meet with the CID for all the details and take that - it wasn't me - and all that. So the funny thing was, I'm there with the CID man and I said, well, how did they think they were going to get away with it? And they said, well, they turn up with them a fake passport of yours, show the ID, and I walk away. I went "right, okay". And they said "they get a passport from either a dead man or they steal one and they replace it with your details and your picture". And the CID man started smirking. The picture they used was this one. And he showed me this fake passport. And I'll tell you what, I was laughing. Then he started chuckling and we laughed about ten minutes, because all they did was, they cut out the picture on the first series of The Office from the DVD. So it's a picture of David Brent sitting behind the desk with that little smug look on his face. That's my passport in this thing. So, I mean, they might have got caught. Anyway.
It's nice to know that even such elaborate operations as this, it still comes down to just Idiocy criminal incompetence who.
Was left in charge, where they go, Dave, you're doing so and so. Julie, you're on the inside. Bertie, can you get a picture?
Yes.
You can get a photograph of Bricky jails, can you?
Yes.
Right, okay. What are you going to HMV for? What are you going to HMV for?
I knew we shouldn't have recruited someone who looks exactly like Bernard Bresslaw.
Karl have you ever been conned?
There's always someone doing well on me. There's always someone - if I go - if they're a little bit short, go round to Pilkington's.

But three or four times a day, sometimes I call him up and he goes, Right, the washing machine's broke and they came around, they've done this right, they couldn't fix it, but they would call it charged 90 quid. I called them back and they said, no, they can't do that. Turns out they can't do it. It's like a string of things where it looks like Karl's handing out money like the end of a comic book. He goes, and that's for the broken window and there's for my sausages. It's like a queue of people just making money off Karl.
They're normally all right if I'm face to face with them.
Really?
Yeah. I can go in a place where a lot of stuff now is done on the phone. It's all phone innit? Because no one's - it's all over the world where you're speaking to these people.
Yeah.

I was talking to someone the other day about the alarm system in the flat, called them up, thought, I will be good to get this going again. Have an alarm system. Haven't had one for years. I might as well use it, it's there. So I called them up and said, yeah, there's an alarm system in this flat I bought. When I get it going again, what's the situation? So they took a load of details and stuff and they said, Right, what you have to do, it's 400 quid a year - I said "what?" - It's a 400 quid a year. I said "What's that for?" - he said, "if the alarm goes off, we can guarantee that a copper will be there in, like, a minute and a half". I said, "I don't want that, I'm just happy with the alarm just going off. I'll give the key to the neighbour". No, you can't do that. You've got to have this way. I said "400..." - I said "I thought alarms are meant to stop you being robbed". "You what sir?" - doesn't understand sarcasm.

Yeah. Just to get out your system, when you know you've been conned, you just laugh in the face of adversity. I remember, um, it was, um, a couple of days before Christmas. I was going away, but I had a dripping tap and it started dripping more, so, uh, there was nothing I could do. The maintenance people were away, the caretaker's away, I couldn't get in a--. So, I uh, I called out an emergency plumber. I knew this was going to cost, but bloke came round. Honestly, he made you look smart. He was like one of those kids who looked like a lumpy child. He was probably 20-
Yeah.
--but he just looked like - you know what I mean? -
Yeah
--they'd scaled up a sort of 13 year old big faced lad.
Yeah, yeah.

Right? He went "Alright?" And he came in and uh, he didn't know how to stop it. He couldn't unscrew it. He went, "I don't know what to do." I called my brother, he's there just- I said, "Uh, Bob, what can I do?" He said, "You could crush the pipe and then get it cut and fixed when you got..." I said, "Great idea." So I said to the plumber, I said, "Can we crush the pipe?" "Oh, yeah, I'll go and get a tool." He went down the van, came up with this thing, like a fat sort of little pair of pliers. He couldn't- he wasn't strong enough, so I went, [Sighs] I had a go. I said, "How about we both do it?" So we both put our hands on it and we managed to crush the pipe, flatten the pipe, cut it off. He put a little thing on the end of it so it wouldn't leak, eh? I went, "Great." Uh, I said, uh, "How much is that?" He went "180 quid." So I went, "Right, okay." So I wrote him out a cheque for 180 quid and I thought I'll have a bit of sarcasm. So it wasn't his idea, I helped him do it. I went, "How much was that tool?" He went, "[Sighs] About a fiver." I went, "That's paid for itself innit?"
[Steve laughs]
Silence - he went, "Yep." Just nothing. Just nothing. Tough crowd. Right?
Yeah, of course.
So I signed the cheque, and he went, "[Sighs]" he said, "I forgot to charge you for the little washer on the end." I went, "How much is that?" He went, "£2.50." I went, "Can I give you that in cash?"
[Steve laughs]

"I written--" He went "Yeah." I went, "There you go, there's- there's the £2.50 for the washer on the end and there's the £180." And he went and that was it. I didn't even get a little chuckle. He didn't even think... He should've gone, "Well, let's split that because we both did that."
Yeah.
"Yeah, that's 90 quid each." I go, "Okay, yeah, that's brilliant mate. Cheers. Here's a Christmas bonus."
[Steve laughs]

I have, uh, a fascinating tale to tell you, Karl. I think you'll be intrigued. Um, when I do, um, junkets for films in, in, America or, uh, Toronto Film Festival, um I was assigned a security. And uh, I've had security before, often have security, they just sort of get you in and out of the car and- usually just to control sort of autograph hunters and things and... But um, this time I was given a security and he came in a suit. He was about 30, he looked quite unassuming. I thought he was from a, just a security firm and there was a couple of them and uh, first of all, they were talking to each other and I thought, "Well, the stakes are higher here, I don't know why." And uh, they drove us to the hotel and there was  uh, loads of people going into the hotel. I mean, much bigger stars than me, you know? There was Ed Norton and- and George Clooney and they were going in and out. And he goes, "I- we can go past these." And he called ahead and he knew everyone, he just knew everyone. And we went down in the car park. We were met by another security guard in the hotel that let us go past everyone. I mean, Clooney's having to queue up and sign. I'm thinking, "This is weird." And I was feeling bit guilty because I was there to promote the film and I think, "This security guard is so good, I'm never going to ever have to bump into anyone." It was amazing.
[Steve laughs]

And he were there the next day and he took us to the junket and back and he put us on the thing and then it turned out that, uh, he was actually LAPD, who was doing this for celebrities 'cause he earned more money. And then um, I found out I had a gun. He said, "I can't come in the airport with you, I can't take my gun." So... he's armed. So I've got a security who's LAPD, who's- who's armed. And I'm fascinated now, I'm fascinated. This man is walking around with me with a little earpiece, talking to everyone, he seems to know everyone, and he's got a gun. I think, "This is amazing." Then one night he said, uh, he dropped me off at the hotel and he said, "Uh, I've actually been called. I've got to go on a mission. They need my help." I said, "What is it?" He said, "It's a hostage situation," he said, "And I'm, I'm also SWAT." So now I'm just- this is amazing. He's now officially the coolest man I've ever met in my life. So he goes off. Then I'm thinking and I'm worried about him. And I was talking to Jane, I was thinking, "Wow, he does this to get some extra cash, he's risking his life, and now he's going to a hostage situation." And I was thinking, "Oh God, it's just- he's just a silent hero."
Mm.
So next day he comes up, I said, "How was it?" He said, "Oh it was fine," he said, "I just turned up," he said, "I had to- I had to do it in my suit," he said, uh, "'cause I'm the negotiator."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]
But he's not bothered, is he? If he's 15 minutes late?
He is bothered. He is 'cos he empathizes with these guys and he says, "no, you've got to understand".
No but the fella' in the house with the gun.
Yeah
He's not going anywhere, 15 minutes, either side doesn't matter. Well, why is he in a rush?
I don't think Karl's getting how important.
I'm not sure he is
You said, you said...
Yeah
They make the car 15 minutes late.
Yeah
He's getting his car, that blocks not in a rush.
He's never going to get in the car, is he? That's the other thing as well, because once a bloke said to him, I need a car, and he just went "where are you going to go?"

And the bloke went, "errr yeah forget that". He has to make them forget their deadlines and their demands so soon It doesn't matter. He has to get in their head. But to do that, he says that he has to empathize with them to a certain extent. He has to understand why they're doing it, to talk to them and go, yeah, you've had a bad day. That would send anyone, but he has to get their trust. Karl, try and talk me out. You think it's that easy. Right, I've got a host situation, I've done a crime. I've run in the building. They go, there's only one person we can ask for. Get me Karl Pilkington. Okay? You turn up, right? What's your questions.
You've asked me to deal with this.

No no no no, the police know that you're their top man. There's a guy in here, he's got a gun, he's got a hostage, okay? He's just done a crime. They don't know what to do. Okay? Right. You turn up. What's your first question to them?
I'm talking to you?
Well no you've got to access...
Right, I'd say, I'd say, Right. Errrrr I think there's a saying, actually. You say "where's Brass?" I found that out. I heard that. I overheard that.
What's that?
It was something...
You're wasting time. Whose that bald cunt whose just turned up? I'm gonna fucking kill..
Listen, Right where's brass?
What does it mean?
I heard it at school
I don't know, the fuck you talking about
You can't just use
It means, I heard someone use it... it means the top person of the police who were around at the moment.
I'm the fucking top brass here. I've got a fucking gun against this kid's head. Who are you you bald little shithead. Where's my car?
What car?
I've asked for a car. Where's my fucking car? Am I talking to you now? Am I?
If you want.
Are you the negotiator?
Yeah.
Right, get me a fucking car.
Where'd you want to go?
I'm fucking sore for shouting through the window. Throw a phone through the window so I can talk to you over the phone.
No. All right, in a minute.
Don't ever fucking say no to me.
In a minute, I said.
Okay.
Right the clocks going. Where's this fucking phone?
Listen.
I've got a sore throat...
Just hang on a moment...
I've got a sore throat, I can't talk anymore.
I've been called up here.
I can't hear you.
I've been called up here.
Yeah. Can you put the phone through? Why are you putting the phone through? You dopey cunt, you want to talk to him.
Because I don't want to give you a phone straight away. You said you've got to delay him.
No, you've got to talk to them. You shouldn't even demand a phone. You should make sure you've got a phone, you dopey twak.
Give him a phone.
Right, thanks. Alright how's it going?
"All right?"
Who are you, by the way? Who are you?
Bruce?
"I can't give you them details."
Well, you can, because I've got to trust you, you dopey sod. Are you police, or just some fucking cunt walking by?
"I'm a policeman."
"Right. I don't trust policemen."
"No, but I'm a bit higher than that."
Ricky and Steve Laugh
"So, listen..."
"Don't you tell me - I'm laying down the law here."
"No, Listen - "
"I'm going to shoot someone unless I get a fast car. I've done a robbery, it's all gone wrong, but I want a car to the airport, I want a plane standing by."
"You don't know me, but I do this a lot, alright? And I can tell you that it never works out, right? Do you know anyone who's done what you're doing and who's now living a happy life?"
"Well, I don't care. I don't care about living anyway. I don't care about living up. I don't care if this goes wrong because I'm going to shoot the hostage - "
What's your problem?
Ricky and Steve Laugh
I think you've got the wrong attitude, mate. I think you've got the wrong attitude 'ere.
"No, but this is, to be honest with you, this was my last week."
Why are you telling him that?
Because I want to bring him down to my level.
Right. "What's that got to do with it?"
"Well, you know, I've done this job for a long time."
"Right"
"Sometimes I felt like you, even though I'm on this side, you know, sometimes I feel like, Oh, I've had enough of this."

"Well, I have had enough. But I'll tell you, I don't care about living or dying here, so if I don't get a car to the airport, all bets are off, I'm killing everyone and then myself. So you'll be a big loser. You will be a big loser, son." There you go, I given you the clue now, Karl. He doesn't care about getting away with it. Now, you've got to get him to stand near a window. You've got to take him out, because I've got a gun to someone's head, you can't burst in, right? Come on. How do you get him to stand near a window?
"Ohh, I bet you're hot in there."
Keep it going, keep going.
"I am, I am hot, that's why I've just drawn the curtain and keeping away from the window, because the sun's blazing and it's not too bad away from the window."
"It's uhhh, the sun's going round the back now, just come and have a look. It's a lovely, lovely, evening."
"Why did you want me to stand near a window?"
"I think just because when you see how nice an evening it is... "
It's the worst, worst, load of drivel ever. It's the worst -
"When you see how..." Keep going, I'm interested, "When you see how lovely an evening it is"
No, it's that thing, that thing, "I've heard that if you smile, you feel better. So have a little smile. Think of a happy moment in your life."
I'll tell you what a happy moment in my life would be. Putting a bullet through your little round head, you cunt!"
"Keep thinking about that image"
Right?
"And you can see that round head. Just come to the window, I'll show you the round head."
That would probably work, actually.
Yeah [Ricky Laughs] "No, I'm not going to come near the window. You come near the window. You come near my window, up you come. Are you coming near the window?"
"No, not yet." Delaying it again. "Right, I'm coming near the window."
[~3 mins of missing transcription]

synopsis.description: Karl has no opinion on Law and Order.

trivia.description: Bernard Bresslaw was a British actor and comedian. He was best known as a member of the Carry On film franchise.
